author: Chris Hook
title: Erth explore new depths in innovation with Prehistoric Aquarium | DailyTelegraph
text:
It’s not often Erth Visual & Physical Inc adds a new show to its repertoire.
The innovative puppetry and special effects troupe is perhaps best known for its forays for children and family audiences into Australia’s ancient geological, cultural and indigenous histories.
Shows such as Erth’s Dinosaur Zoo, The Dream Of The Thylacine and I, Bunyip were all carefully researched and painstakingly crafted, often taking years to create with the various creatures rendered in accurate and dramatic detail, brought to life via inventive puppetry and ingenious use of technology.
Prehistoric Aquarium, now enjoying a premiere season at the company’s Carriageworks base is a fitting addition to the company’s roster.
Again intended for younger audiences and their families, the work continues Erth’s examination of Australia’s ancient past, this time going back way before the dinosaurs to the beginning of complex multicellular life in our oceans.
The conceit in which this unfolds is that of an aquarium-driven lecture hosted by a chap called Drew, introduced as a marketing manager for “Erth’s Underwater Aquarium” and whose vacuous obsession with celebrity and pizzazz around the show is a kind of satire of particular types of characters one encounters in the theatre sector.

It then moves through to the evolution of various ocean-dwelling beasts right up to the kinds of things we could expect to see in the deepest depths even now, an area of our world even less explored than the space beyond it.
To do this the Prehistoric Aquarium deploys a screen that acts as a kind of tank, the animals coming to life on it and behind it, some as shadow puppets, some as projections others as full-sized puppets. Later light and fibre-optic cable is used beautifully to illustrate the kind of bioluminescence that occurs in the depths.
As with many Erth shows, younger viewers are invited to sit on the floor right in front of the action, with a small group of older kids taking part in the show as “interns”, appropriately dressed in suits reminiscent of old-timey diving gear.
Inevitably, disaster strikes and the aquarium bursts open, the larger animals swimming around and above the audience.
While it’s not as immediately dramatic as the dinosaur or indigenous mythology shows, there is a hypnotic, meditative quality to the piece. And it pushes Erth’s concern with audience participation and immersion a little bit further, the “interns” taking part in a fuller kind of way, acting as proxies for the rest of us.
And there is so much in it that is so deftly deployed there’s no sense of being in a class.
Erth’s Prehistoric Aquarium is a great value school holiday experience, ideal for the five and over set and a great addition to the company’s repertoire.
Erth’s Prehistoric Aquarium, Carriageworks, 245 Wilson St, Eveleigh; 10am and noon, until October 4, $25, erth.com.au
